segment.source: Composition animations
segment.target: Composition animations

segment.source: Many composition object and effect properties can be animated using key frame and expression animations allowing properties of a UI element to change over time or based on a calculation.
segment.target: Many composition object and effect properties can be animated using key frame and expression animations allowing properties of a UI element to change over time or based on a calculation.

segment.source: Composition animations
segment.target: Composition animations

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Many composition object and effect properties can be animated using key frame and expression animations allowing properties of a UI element to change over time or based on a calculation.
segment.target: Many composition object and effect properties can be animated using key frame and expression animations allowing properties of a UI element to change over time or based on a calculation.

segment.source: There are two types of animations, keyframe animations, represented by the KeyFrameAnimation class, and expression animations represented by the ExpressionAnimation class.
segment.target: There are two types of animations, keyframe animations, represented by the KeyFrameAnimation class, and expression animations represented by the ExpressionAnimation class.

segment.target: Animatable Properties

segment.target: KeyFrame Animations

segment.target: The following properties are animatable by associating them with a KeyFrame or Expression Animation:

segment.target: CompositionColorBrush.Color

segment.target: InsetClip.BottomInset

segment.target: InsetClip.LeftInset

segment.target: InsetClip.RightInset

segment.source: InsetClip.TopInset
segment.target: InsetClip.TopInset

segment.target: Visual.AnchorPoint

segment.source: Visual.CenterPoint
segment.target: Visual.CenterPoint

segment.target: Visual.Offset

segment.source: Visual.Opacity
segment.target: Visual.Opacity

segment.source: Visual.Orientation
segment.target: Visual.Orientation

segment.source: Visual.RotationAngle
segment.target: Visual.RotationAngle

segment.source: Visual.RotationAxis
segment.target: Visual.RotationAxis

segment.source: Visual.Size
segment.target: Visual.Size

segment.target: Visual.TransformMatrix

segment.target: CompositionPropertySet

segment.source: KeyFrame Animations
segment.target: KeyFrame Animations

segment.source: KeyFrame Animations are time-based animations that use one or more key frames to specify how the animated value should change over time.
segment.target: KeyFrame Animations are time-based animations that use one or more key frames to specify how the animated value should change over time.

segment.source: The frames represent markers, allowing you to define what the animated value should be at a specific time.
segment.target: The frames represent markers, allowing you to define what the animated value should be at a specific time.

segment.source: Creating your animation and KeyFrames
segment.target: Creating your animation and KeyFrames

segment.source: To construct a KeyFrame Animation, use one of the constructor methods of the Compositor class that correlates to the structure type of the property you wish to animate.
segment.target: To construct a KeyFrame Animation, use one of the constructor methods of the Compositor class that correlates to the structure type of the property you wish to animate.

segment.source: CreateColorKeyFrameAnimation
segment.target: CreateColorKeyFrameAnimation

segment.source: CreateQuaternionKeyFrameAnimation
segment.target: CreateQuaternionKeyFrameAnimation

segment.source: CreateScalarKeyFrameAnimation
segment.target: CreateScalarKeyFrameAnimation

segment.source: CreateVector2KeyFrameAnimation
segment.target: CreateVector2KeyFrameAnimation

segment.source: CreateVector3KeyFrameAnimation
segment.target: CreateVector3KeyFrameAnimation

segment.source: CreateVector4KeyFrameAnimation
segment.target: CreateVector4KeyFrameAnimation

segment.source: For example, the following snippet creates a Vector3 keyframe animation:
segment.target: For example, the following snippet creates a Vector3 keyframe animation:

segment.source: Each KeyFrame is constructed by calling the InsertKeyFrame method of a KeyFrameAnimation and specifying two components and optionally a third component:
segment.target: Each KeyFrame is constructed by calling the InsertKeyFrame method of a KeyFrameAnimation and specifying two components and optionally a third component:

segment.source: Time: normalized progress state of the KeyFrame between 0.0 – 1.0
segment.target: Time: normalized progress state of the KeyFrame between 0.0 – 1.0

segment.source: Value: specific value of the animating value at the time state
segment.target: Value: specific value of the animating value at the time state

segment.source: (Optional) Easing function: function to describe interpolation between previous and current KeyFrame (discussed later on)
segment.target: (Optional) Easing function: function to describe interpolation between previous and current KeyFrame (discussed later on)

segment.source: For example, the following snippet inserts a keyframe in a Vector3KeyFrameAnimation that will triggered half way through the animation:
segment.target: For example, the following snippet inserts a keyframe in a Vector3KeyFrameAnimation that will triggered half way through the animation:

segment.source: KeyFrame Properties
segment.target: KeyFrame Properties

segment.source: Once you've defined your KeyFrame Animation and the individual KeyFrames, you are able to define multiple properties of your animation:
segment.target: Once you've defined your KeyFrame Animation and the individual KeyFrames, you are able to define multiple properties of your animation:

segment.source: DelayTime – time before an animation starts after StartAnimation() is called
segment.target: DelayTime – time before an animation starts after StartAnimation() is called

segment.source: Duration – duration of the animation
segment.target: Duration – duration of the animation

segment.source: IterationBehavior – count or infinite repeat behavior for an animation
segment.target: IterationBehavior – count or infinite repeat behavior for an animation

segment.source: IterationCount – number of finite times a KeyFrame Animation will repeat
segment.target: IterationCount – number of finite times a KeyFrame Animation will repeat

segment.source: KeyFrame Count – number of KeyFrames in a particular KeyFrameAnimation
segment.target: KeyFrame Count – number of KeyFrames in a particular KeyFrameAnimation

segment.source: StopBehavior – specifies the behavior of an animating property value when StopAnimation is called.
segment.target: StopBehavior – specifies the behavior of an animating property value when StopAnimation is called.

segment.source: For example, the following snippet sets the duration of the animation to five seconds:
segment.target: For example, the following snippet sets the duration of the animation to five seconds:

segment.source: Easing Functions
segment.target: Easing Functions

segment.source: A key frame easing function, a CompositionEasingFunction, indicates how intermediate values progress from the previous key frame value to the current key frame value.
segment.target: A key frame easing function, a CompositionEasingFunction, indicates how intermediate values progress from the previous key frame value to the current key frame value.

segment.source: If you do not provide an easing function for the KeyFrame, a default curve will be used.
segment.target: If you do not provide an easing function for the KeyFrame, a default curve will be used.

segment.source: There are two types of easing functions supported:
segment.target: There are two types of easing functions supported:

segment.source: Linear (LinearEasingFunction)
segment.target: Linear (LinearEasingFunction)

segment.source: Cubic Bezier (CubicBezierEasingFunction)
segment.target: Cubic Bezier (CubicBezierEasingFunction)

segment.source: To create an easing function, use either the CreateLinearEasingFunction or CreateCubicBezierEasingFunction method of the Compositor class:
segment.target: To create an easing function, use either the CreateLinearEasingFunction or CreateCubicBezierEasingFunction method of the Compositor class:

segment.source: Note: A useful tool for generating the points for your Cubic Bezier can be found here.
segment.target: Note: A useful tool for generating the points for your Cubic Bezier can be found here.

segment.source: To add your easing function into your KeyFrame, simply add in the third parameter to the KeyFrame when inserting it into the Animation:
segment.target: To add your easing function into your KeyFrame, simply add in the third parameter to the KeyFrame when inserting it into the Animation:

segment.source: Starting and Stopping KeyFrame Animations
segment.target: Starting and Stopping KeyFrame Animations

segment.source: After you have defined your animation, KeyFrames and properties, you are ready to connect the animation to the property you want to animate.
segment.target: After you have defined your animation, KeyFrames and properties, you are ready to connect the animation to the property you want to animate.

segment.source: You connect your animation to the property you plan to animate by calling StartAnimation on the Visual object the property belongs to.
segment.target: You connect your animation to the property you plan to animate by calling StartAnimation on the Visual object the property belongs to.

segment.source: The general syntax and an example is as follows:
segment.target: The general syntax and an example is as follows:

segment.source: After starting your animation, you also have the ability to stop and disconnect it as well.
segment.target: After starting your animation, you also have the ability to stop and disconnect it as well.

segment.source: This is done by using the StopAnimation method and specifying the property you want to stop animating.
segment.target: This is done by using the StopAnimation method and specifying the property you want to stop animating.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Animation Completion Events
segment.target: Animation Completion Events

segment.source: KeyFrame animations have a defined end, unlike Expression Animations, which are conditional.
segment.target: KeyFrame animations have a defined end, unlike Expression Animations, which are conditional.

segment.source: Developers can determine when groups or a single KeyFrame animation completes by using batches.
segment.target: Developers can determine when groups or a single KeyFrame animation completes by using batches.

segment.source: Batches can be created or retrieved, depending on the batch object type, and are used to aggregate the end state of animations.
segment.target: Batches can be created or retrieved, depending on the batch object type, and are used to aggregate the end state of animations.

segment.source: Scoped batches are created while Commit batches are retrieved, the use of these different batches are described later.
segment.target: Scoped batches are created while Commit batches are retrieved, the use of these different batches are described later.

segment.source: A batch completion event fires when all animations within the batch have completed.
segment.target: A batch completion event fires when all animations within the batch have completed.

segment.source: The time it takes for a batch's completion event to fire depends on the longest or most delayed animation in the batch.
segment.target: The time it takes for a batch's completion event to fire depends on the longest or most delayed animation in the batch.

segment.source: Aggregating end states is useful when you need to know when groups of select animations complete in order to schedule other work.
segment.target: Aggregating end states is useful when you need to know when groups of select animations complete in order to schedule other work.

segment.source: Scoped batches
segment.target: Scoped batches

segment.source: To aggregate a specific group or a single animation, you first need to create a Scoped batch by calling CreateScopedBatch.
segment.target: To aggregate a specific group or a single animation, you first need to create a Scoped batch by calling CreateScopedBatch.

segment.source: After creating a Scoped batch, all started animations aggregate until the batch is explicitly suspended or ended using Suspend or End.
segment.target: After creating a Scoped batch, all started animations aggregate until the batch is explicitly suspended or ended using Suspend or End.

segment.source: Calling Suspend stops aggregating animation end states until Resume is called.
segment.target: Calling Suspend stops aggregating animation end states until Resume is called.

segment.source: This allows you to explicitly exclude content from a given batch.
segment.target: This allows you to explicitly exclude content from a given batch.

segment.source: In order to complete your batch you must call End.
segment.target: In order to complete your batch you must call End.

segment.source: Without an End call, the batch will remain open forever-collecting objects.
segment.target: Without an End call, the batch will remain open forever-collecting objects.

segment.source: If you want to know when a single animation ends, you need to create a Scoped batch, start the animation and end the batch.
segment.target: If you want to know when a single animation ends, you need to create a Scoped batch, start the animation and end the batch.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Commit batches
segment.target: Commit batches

segment.source: A commit batch is a batch that is implicitly created during the commit cycle.
segment.target: A commit batch is a batch that is implicitly created during the commit cycle.

segment.source: The current Commit batch can be retrieved by calling GetCommitBatch at any time during the commit cycle.
segment.target: The current Commit batch can be retrieved by calling GetCommitBatch at any time during the commit cycle.

segment.source: The commit cycle is defined as the time between updates from the compositor.
segment.target: The commit cycle is defined as the time between updates from the compositor.

segment.source: Updates are queued until the system is ready to process the changes and draw bits to the screen.
segment.target: Updates are queued until the system is ready to process the changes and draw bits to the screen.

segment.source: Titles do not control when commits happen.
segment.target: Titles do not control when commits happen.

segment.source: The Commit batch will aggregate all objects within the commit cycle, those before and after GetCommitBatch was called.
segment.target: The Commit batch will aggregate all objects within the commit cycle, those before and after GetCommitBatch was called.

segment.source: There is only one Commit batch per commit cycle and you do not need to explicitly call End on the commit batch.
segment.target: There is only one Commit batch per commit cycle and you do not need to explicitly call End on the commit batch.

segment.source: Batch states
segment.target: Batch states

segment.source: To determine if a batch is open to aggregating animations you can use the IsActive property.
segment.target: To determine if a batch is open to aggregating animations you can use the IsActive property.

segment.source: If the IsEnded property return true, you cannot add an animation to that specific batch.
segment.target: If the IsEnded property return true, you cannot add an animation to that specific batch.

segment.source: Scoped batches are “ended” when they have been explicitly ended by calling the End method.
segment.target: Scoped batches are “ended” when they have been explicitly ended by calling the End method.

segment.source: Commit batches are ended when the current commit cycle has ended.
segment.target: Commit batches are ended when the current commit cycle has ended.

segment.source: Expression Animations
segment.target: Expression Animations

segment.source: Expression Animations are animations that use a mathematical expression to specify how the animated value should be calculated for each frame.
segment.target: Expression Animations are animations that use a mathematical expression to specify how the animated value should be calculated for each frame.

segment.source: The expression language itself can reference properties from other composition objects.
segment.target: The expression language itself can reference properties from other composition objects.

segment.source: Unlike KeyFrame Animations, Expressions are not time-based and are processed each frame (if necessary).
segment.target: Unlike KeyFrame Animations, Expressions are not time-based and are processed each frame (if necessary).

segment.source: Expressions can be useful to describe more complex user experiences that can be processed by the Composition engine, for example sticky headers and parallax.
segment.target: Expressions can be useful to describe more complex user experiences that can be processed by the Composition engine, for example sticky headers and parallax.

segment.source: Creating your Expression
segment.target: Creating your Expression

segment.source: To create your expression, you call CreateExpressionAnimation on your Compositor object and specifying the expression you want to use:
segment.target: To create your expression, you call CreateExpressionAnimation on your Compositor object and specifying the expression you want to use:

segment.source: Operators, Precedence and Associativity
segment.target: Operators, Precedence and Associativity

segment.source: The Expression language supports the following operators and adheres to operator precedence and associativity as defined in the C# Language Specification:
segment.target: The Expression language supports the following operators and adheres to operator precedence and associativity as defined in the C# Language Specification:

segment.source: Unary (-)
segment.target: Unary (-)

segment.source: Multiplicative (\* /)
segment.target: Multiplicative (\* /)

segment.source: Additive (- +)
segment.target: Additive (- +)

segment.source: The Expression language also supports the concept of per-component math operations.
segment.target: The Expression language also supports the concept of per-component math operations.

segment.source: These member-access (x.y) operators are only supported on “primitive” types (Vector and Matrices).
segment.target: These member-access (x.y) operators are only supported on “primitive” types (Vector and Matrices).

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Property Parameters
segment.target: Property Parameters

segment.source: One of the powerful components of the Expression language is being able use parameters as variables in the expression.
segment.target: One of the powerful components of the Expression language is being able use parameters as variables in the expression.

segment.source: The expression string can contain parameters which are replaced with either a constant value or are references to another object's property value when calculated.
segment.target: The expression string can contain parameters which are replaced with either a constant value or are references to another object's property value when calculated.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: In this example ChildOffset and ParentOffset are parameters that represent the offset property of two visuals.
segment.target: In this example ChildOffset and ParentOffset are parameters that represent the offset property of two visuals.

segment.source: You define parameters using the Set\*Parameter methods of the CompositionAnimation class:
segment.target: You define parameters using the Set\*Parameter methods of the CompositionAnimation class:

segment.source: To create a vector parameter you use SetVector2Parameter, SetVector3Parameter, or SetVector4Parameter.
segment.target: To create a vector parameter you use SetVector2Parameter, SetVector3Parameter, or SetVector4Parameter.

segment.source: To create a matrix parameter you use SetMatrix3x2Parameter, or SetMatrix4x4Parameter.
segment.target: To create a matrix parameter you use SetMatrix3x2Parameter, or SetMatrix4x4Parameter.

segment.source: to create a scalar parameter you use SetScalarParameter.
segment.target: to create a scalar parameter you use SetScalarParameter.

segment.source: To create a color parameter you use SetColorParameter.
segment.target: To create a color parameter you use SetColorParameter.

segment.source: To create a quaternion parameter you use SetQuaternionParameter.
segment.target: To create a quaternion parameter you use SetQuaternionParameter.

segment.source: To create a reference parameter you use SetReferenceParameter.
segment.target: To create a reference parameter you use SetReferenceParameter.

segment.source: In the Expression String above, we would need to create two parameters to define the two Visuals:
segment.target: In the Expression String above, we would need to create two parameters to define the two Visuals:

segment.source: Expression Helper Functions
segment.target: Expression Helper Functions

segment.source: In addition to having access to operators and property parameters, you also have access to the full helper function library of the expression language.
segment.target: In addition to having access to operators and property parameters, you also have access to the full helper function library of the expression language.

segment.source: You can find the full list of helper functions in the remarks section of the ExpressionAnimation class, but here are a few:
segment.target: You can find the full list of helper functions in the remarks section of the ExpressionAnimation class, but here are a few:

segment.source: Max (Scalar value1, Scalar value2)
segment.target: Max (Scalar value1, Scalar value2)

segment.source: Scale (Vector3 value, Scalar factor)
segment.target: Scale (Vector3 value, Scalar factor)

segment.source: Transform(Vector2 value, Matrix 3x2 matrix)
segment.target: Transform(Vector2 value, Matrix 3x2 matrix)

segment.source: Here’s a more complex expression string example that uses the Clamp helper function:
segment.target: Here’s a more complex expression string example that uses the Clamp helper function:

segment.source: Starting and stopping your Expression Animation
segment.target: Starting and stopping your Expression Animation

segment.source: To start and stop your Expression Animations, you use the same functions (StartAnimation, StopAnimation) as you do with KeyFrame Animations.
segment.target: To start and stop your Expression Animations, you use the same functions (StartAnimation, StopAnimation) as you do with KeyFrame Animations.

segment.source: Note: Expression Animations will continue to run until they are stopped using StopAnimation – unlike KeyFrame Animations, they do not have a finite duration.
segment.target: Note: Expression Animations will continue to run until they are stopped using StopAnimation – unlike KeyFrame Animations, they do not have a finite duration.

segment.source: Property Sets
segment.target: Property Sets

segment.source: In addition to being able to reference properties of other Composition objects, you also have the ability to create and store property values of your own that can be used across multiple animations.
segment.target: In addition to being able to reference properties of other Composition objects, you also have the ability to create and store property values of your own that can be used across multiple animations.

segment.source: Property sets are represented by the CompositionPropertySet class.
segment.target: Property sets are represented by the CompositionPropertySet class.

segment.source: Property sets allow you to create a property with a value and reference it later in an expression or even hook it up as the target of a KeyFrame Animation.
segment.target: Property sets allow you to create a property with a value and reference it later in an expression or even hook it up as the target of a KeyFrame Animation.

segment.source: To create a property set, use the CreatePropertySet method of the Compositor class.
segment.target: To create a property set, use the CreatePropertySet method of the Compositor class.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Once you’ve created your property set, you can add a property and value to it using one of the Insert\* methods of CompositionPropertySet.
segment.target: Once you’ve created your property set, you can add a property and value to it using one of the Insert\* methods of CompositionPropertySet.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: After you've created your expression animation, you can reference properties from the property set in the expression string with the use of a reference parameter.
segment.target: After you've created your expression animation, you can reference properties from the property set in the expression string with the use of a reference parameter.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Expression KeyFrames
segment.target: Expression KeyFrames

segment.source: Earlier in this document, we described how you create KeyFrame Animations and their respective KeyFrames.
segment.target: Earlier in this document, we described how you create KeyFrame Animations and their respective KeyFrames.

segment.source: In addition to making the traditional KeyFrame with a normalized time and value component, you are also able to define expression KeyFrames.
segment.target: In addition to making the traditional KeyFrame with a normalized time and value component, you are also able to define expression KeyFrames.

segment.source: Instead of defining an explicit value for a particular time in the KeyFrame, we are able to use the expression syntax to describe how the value should be calculated at this particular point in the KeyFrame timeline.
segment.target: Instead of defining an explicit value for a particular time in the KeyFrame, we are able to use the expression syntax to describe how the value should be calculated at this particular point in the KeyFrame timeline.

segment.source: You are able to mix and match expression KeyFrames with basic KeyFrames in your KeyFrame Animation.
segment.target: You are able to mix and match expression KeyFrames with basic KeyFrames in your KeyFrame Animation.

segment.source: Constructing Expression KeyFrames
segment.target: Constructing Expression KeyFrames

segment.source: Similar to traditional KeyFrames, expression KeyFrames are constructed by specifying 2 components:
segment.target: Similar to traditional KeyFrames, expression KeyFrames are constructed by specifying 2 components:

segment.source: Time: normalized time state of the KeyFrame between 0.0 – 1.0
segment.target: Time: normalized time state of the KeyFrame between 0.0 – 1.0

segment.source: Value: The expression string used to describe how the value should be calculated
segment.target: Value: The expression string used to describe how the value should be calculated

segment.source: For example, the following snippet uses a combination of both regular and expression KeyFrames:
segment.target: For example, the following snippet uses a combination of both regular and expression KeyFrames:

segment.source: Using current and starting values
segment.target: Using current and starting values

segment.source: In the expression language, it is possible to reference both the current and the starting value of an animation.
segment.target: In the expression language, it is possible to reference both the current and the starting value of an animation.

segment.source: These values are pre-fixed in the expression language with “this”:
segment.target: These values are pre-fixed in the expression language with “this”:

segment.source: this.CurrentValue
segment.target: this.CurrentValue

segment.source: this.StartingValue
segment.target: this.StartingValue

segment.source: An example of using these in an Expression KeyFrame:
segment.target: An example of using these in an Expression KeyFrame:

segment.source: Conditional Expressions
segment.target: Conditional Expressions

segment.source: In addition to supporting basic mathematical expressions, you can also define a conditional expression using a ternary operator:
segment.target: In addition to supporting basic mathematical expressions, you can also define a conditional expression using a ternary operator:

segment.source: Within the expressions themselves, the following conditional operators are supported in the condition statement:
segment.target: Within the expressions themselves, the following conditional operators are supported in the condition statement:

segment.source: Equals (==)
segment.target: Equals (==)

segment.source: Not Equals (!=)
segment.target: Not Equals (!=)

segment.source: Less than (<)
segment.target: Less than (<)

segment.source: Less than or equal to (<=)
segment.target: Less than or equal to (<=)

segment.source: Great than (>)
segment.target: Great than (>)

segment.source: Great than or equal to (>=)
segment.target: Great than or equal to (>=)

segment.source: Finally, the following conjunctions are supported as operators or functions in the condition statement:
segment.target: Finally, the following conjunctions are supported as operators or functions in the condition statement:

segment.source: Not: !
segment.target: Not: !

segment.source: / Not(bool1)
segment.target: / Not(bool1)

segment.source: And: && / And(bool1, bool2)
segment.target: And: && / And(bool1, bool2)

segment.source: Or: || / Or(bool1, bool2)
segment.target: Or: || / Or(bool1, bool2)

segment.source: The following snippet shows an example of using conditionals in an expression:
segment.target: The following snippet shows an example of using conditionals in an expression:
